awd_titl_txt: Photoelectron-Photofragment Coincidence Studies of the Dynamics of Decarboxylation
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms -A (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Robert Continetti of the University of California, San Diego is using laser optical techniques to study the decarboxylation reactions of various organic molecules including carboxylic acids, fatty acids, and esters.  The term decarboxylation refers to the removal of carbon dioxide (CO2) from the molecule.  A common carboxylic acid is acetic acid (C2H4O2), the distinctive component of vinegar.  Decarboxylation of acetic acid gives CO2 and methane (CH4).   Fatty acids are carboxylic acids with very long carbon+hydrogen chains.  Fatty acids are what constitute animal fat and vegetable oils.   The process of decarboxylation plays a key role in complex phenomena ranging from the Krebs acid cycle used by many organisms to release stored energy, to new particle formation in the chemistry of atmospheric aerosols. In spite of the importance, little is known about the mechanism of the elimination of carbon dioxide that occurs in decarboxylation.  The Continetti research group uses a technique called photoelectron-photofragment coincidence (PPC) spectroscopy. In the PPC experiment, a beam of the carboxylic acid (actually a negatively charged form) is directed into a vacuum chamber, and the beam is exposed to a strong laser beam, which ejects an electron from the acid molecule. The resulting molecule is unstable, and falls apart into CO2 and hydrocarbon fragments.  PPC spectroscopy measures the speed (and kinetic energy) of the ejected electron and the CO2 and hydrocarbon fragments, and therefore provides insights into how the laser light energy is absorbed by the acid molecule and leads to fragmentation.  This research project is providing fundamental insights not only into the chemical process of decarboxylation,  but to molecular fragmentation in general. It is also likely to contribute to our understanding of biofuel combustion and other complex chemical phenomena. In addition to the basic science questions, researchers engaged in this research project are gaining valuable experience in the design and operation of a novel experimental apparatus, the analysis of multifaceted data, and the computer simulation of molecular ion motions. This research project provides opportunities for the training of students and postdoctoral associates in the design and construction of novel experimental instrumentation and complex data analysis.

Decarboxylation is a fundamental process in chemistry driven by the thermodynamic stability of CO2, with implications for biology, combustion and atmospheric chemistry. In this project, decarboxylation is studied using the dissociative photodetachment of precursor anions synthesized by proton abstraction from carboxylic acid precursors. The heavy ion PPC spectrometer provides the opportunity to directly examine the full gamut of dissociation pathways including anionic photodissociation (PD) and dissociative photodetachment (DPD) for large species of interest. The PPC spectroscopy measurements are focusing on a series of complex anions that are expected to undergo decarboxylation, including the carboxylate anions, dicarboxylate dianions and fatty acids, probing the full range of low energy decomposition pathways accessible following photoabsorption. This project seeks to reveal new insights into the role of intramolecular hydrogen bonding on the relative energetics and dissociation dynamics. Finally, the dissociation dynamics of the methyl- and ethyl-esters of long chain saturated and unsaturated fatty acids of relevance to biofuels are also being studied, providing benchmark energetics data that can aid in the validation of theoretical calculations in complex ions and radicals. The broader impacts of this work include potential societal benefits from understanding decarboxylation dynamics of relevance to the atmosphere and biology, as well as providing training opportunities for graduate students and postdoctoral associates in the program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project used a unique experimental apparatus developed with NSF support for the study of fundamental properties of complex negative molecular ions in the gas phase. The apparatus, known as the high-beam-energy photoelectron-photofragment-coincidence (PPC) spectrometer for complex anions, allows the use of photodetachment of negative ions as a tool for understanding the reactivity and energetics of the corresponding neutral molecules using the technique of PPC spectroscopy. PPC spectroscopy provides these insights by measuring the kinetic energies of the photoelectron and photofragments in coincidence, providing a kinematically complete measurement of the dynamics of dissociative photodetachment. What this means is that we excite the negative ion with a photon, observe how it breaks up into a free electron and neutral reaction products, and detect all of those products at the same time, ‘in coincidence’. This allows us to map out the the chemistry of transient species more completely than other measurements that are not carried out in coincidence. A specific focus of these studies has been on the carboxylate anions and their derivatives that play a key role in the oxidation of organic compounds in systems that range from biological, to combustion, to environmental chemistry, yet are often poorly understood at a fundamental level.

The experiments carried out under this grant expanded our studies of carboxylate anions and decarboxylation reactions that occur in them. Two important take home messages arise from these studies. First, in unsubstituted carboxyl radicals, the dynamics are dominated by the carboxylate functional group with a secondary effect of the substituent ‘R’ group based on stabilization of either the carboxylate or the neutral carboxyl formed by photodetachment. This effect plays out in the benzoate, phenyl acetate and p-coumarate anions studied in the beginning of the grant period. The second take home message is that when the presence of the substituent ‘R’ group includes conjugation with a carbonyl group, as in the alpha-keto-carboxylates, the photochemistry becomes much richer. Recently two groups have studied the simplest of these molecules, the pyruvate anion, using photoelectron spectroscopy alone. Both of those studies analyzed the excited state ionic photochemistry as based on the well known n → π* valence transitions in the carbonyl by analogy to the corresponding neutral molecule, pyruvic acid. Our more complete photoelectron-photofragment coincidence studies provide strong evidence instead that the chemistry is dominated by the interaction of the excess electron on the carboxylate moiety with the exciting photon. Our work shows that both ionic photodissociation and dissociative photodetachment proceed by a common dissociation mechanism as the photofragments recoil. In our view the ionic photodissociation process arises from photoexcitation of the excess electron slightly above the photodetachment threshold into a diffuse carbonyl-centered dipole-bound that is coupled with the excited valence orbitals invoked by the other researchers. This electron-molecule interaction can then induce dissociation, electron emission during dissociation, and, through intramolecular electron transfer and localization of the electron on one of the dissociation fragments, such as the acetyl anion observed from photoexcitation of pyruvate.  This is a fundamentally different way to view the photochemistry in these types of molecules, and should provide the motivation for a broader theoretical examination of this type of chemistry that could play an important role in atmospheric and low-temperature plasma chemistry as well as condensed-phase biological processes.

The intrinsic value of this work lies in the development of a new technique for experimental studies of more complex molecular negative ions than previously possible. The data obtained in these studies provides new insights into energetics and reactivity and experimental benchmarks against which theoretical predictions about the energetics and reactivity of molecular negative ions and neutral radicals and molecule can be evaluated. The broader scientific impacts include an expanded knowledge of the photochemistry of carboxylate anions and substituted carboxylate anions, with implications ranging from biology to atmospheric and combustion chemistry.

One of the most important broader impacts of this work is the training it provides researchers at all levels. Designing, building and demonstrating state-of-the-art scientific equipment provides outstanding training for the scientists of tomorrow who will help solve society’s many challenging problems that require scientific input. As a validation of this view, the graduate student working on this project received her PhD in 2024 and is now an NRC postdoctoral fellow at the Naval Surface Weapons laboratory at China Lake, CA. Regrettably our efforts to carry out broader outreach efforts to other graduate students, undergraduates and high school students were negatively impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic and did not come to fruition.

 


Last Modified: 01/01/2025
Modified by: Robert E Continetti
